name: Phishing Email Detection
description: Learn to identify phishing emails, suspicious links, and fraudulent sender addresses.

questions.title: You receive an email from 'security@amaz0n-support.com' asking you to verify your account. What should you do?
options: Click the link and verify your account
Forward it to your IT department and delete it
Ignore it but keep it in your inbox
questions.correct_answer: Forward it to your IT department and delete it
questions.explanation: The domain 'amaz0n-support.com' uses a zero instead of 'o' - a common phishing tactic. Always report suspicious emails to IT.

questions.title: Phishing emails always contain spelling and grammar mistakes.
questions.explanation: Sophisticated phishing attacks can be perfectly written with proper grammar. Don't rely on errors alone to identify phishing.

questions.title: Which of the following is the BEST indicator that an email might be a phishing attempt?
options: The email has a company logo
The sender's email domain doesn't match the company they claim to represent
The email was sent during business hours
The email has a professional signature
questions.correct_answer: The sender's email domain doesn't match the company they claim to represent
questions.explanation: Mismatched domains are a key phishing indicator. Legitimate companies send from their official domains.

questions.title: If a website has HTTPS and a padlock icon, it is guaranteed to be safe and legitimate.
questions.explanation: HTTPS only means the connection is encrypted. Phishing sites can also have HTTPS certificates.

questions.title: An email with an attachment named 'Invoice_12345.pdf.exe' arrives. What type of file is this actually?
options: An executable program that could be malware
questions.correct_answer: An executable program that could be malware
questions.explanation: Double extensions like '.pdf.exe' hide malicious executables. The real extension is .exe - never open these.

questions.title: You receive an email from your bank asking you to click a link to verify suspicious activity on your account.
questions.explanation: Banks rarely ask customers to click email links. Always log into your bank directly through their official website.

questions.title: What is 'spear phishing'?
options: Targeted phishing using personal information about the victim
questions.correct_answer: Targeted phishing using personal information about the victim
questions.explanation: Spear phishing is personalized and researched, making it more convincing and dangerous than generic phishing.

questions.title: Legitimate IT support may ask for your password via email to troubleshoot issues.
questions.explanation: Legitimate IT departments NEVER ask for passwords via email. This is always a phishing attempt.

questions.title: You hover over a link in an email and see it points to 'bit.ly/xyz123'. What should you do?
options: Click it since short links are convenient
Avoid clicking - URL shorteners hide the real destination
Click it only if the email looks professional
Copy and paste it into your browser
questions.correct_answer: Avoid clicking - URL shorteners hide the real destination
questions.explanation: URL shorteners can hide malicious destinations. Legitimate businesses rarely use them in official communications.

questions.title: An email from a colleague asks you to wire $5,000 urgently for a business deal. They mention they're in a meeting and can't talk.
questions.explanation: This is Business Email Compromise (BEC). Always verify financial requests via phone using a known number.

questions.title: What is 'whaling' in cybersecurity?
options: Phishing attacks targeting executives and high-level employees
questions.correct_answer: Phishing attacks targeting executives and high-level employees
questions.explanation: Whaling targets 'big fish' - executives with access to sensitive data and financial authority.

questions.title: An email that addresses you by your full name and job title cannot be a phishing attempt.
questions.explanation: Attackers research targets using LinkedIn and company websites. Personal details don't guarantee legitimacy.

questions.title: Which email header can help identify spoofed emails?
options: The 'Reply-To' address differs from the 'From' address
questions.correct_answer: The 'Reply-To' address differs from the 'From' address
questions.explanation: When Reply-To differs from From, responses go to a different address - often controlled by attackers.

questions.title: You receive a job offer email with an amazing salary for a remote position you never applied for.
questions.explanation: Unsolicited job offers with unrealistic benefits are commonly used to harvest personal information.

questions.title: What technique uses domains like 'g00gle.com' or 'paypa1.com'?
questions.explanation: Typosquatting uses misspelled or look-alike domains to trick users into visiting fake sites.

questions.title: Clone phishing duplicates a legitimate email but replaces links with malicious ones.
questions.explanation: Clone phishing copies real emails you've received before, making them highly convincing.

questions.title: An email claims to be from Microsoft at 'microsoft.com.malicious-site.com'. What is the actual domain?
questions.explanation: The actual domain is before the first single slash. 'microsoft.com' here is just a subdomain of malicious-site.com.

questions.title: An email from Netflix says your payment failed and includes a link to 'netflix-billing-update.com' to fix it.
questions.explanation: Netflix's official domain is netflix.com. Any variation like 'netflix-billing-update.com' is fake.

questions.title: What is the SAFEST way to verify if an email from your bank is legitimate?
options: Call the number in the email
Log into your bank directly through their official website
questions.correct_answer: Log into your bank directly through their official website
questions.explanation: Never use links or phone numbers from suspicious emails. Navigate directly to official websites.

questions.title: Some phishing emails intentionally include spelling errors to filter out cautious users.
questions.explanation: Intentional errors filter out vigilant users, leaving only those likely to fall for the full scam.

name: Social Engineering Defense
description: Understand manipulation tactics including pretexting, baiting, tailgating, and psychological manipulation.

questions.title: Someone calls claiming to be from IT and asks for your password to 'verify your account'. What should you do?
options: Ask for their employee ID and then provide it
Refuse and report the call to your actual IT department
questions.correct_answer: Refuse and report the call to your actual IT department
questions.explanation: Legitimate IT staff NEVER ask for passwords. This is a classic pretexting attack.

questions.title: Pretexting involves creating a fabricated scenario to manipulate victims into revealing information.
questions.explanation: Pretexting creates fictional scenarios (pretexts) to gain trust and extract sensitive information.

questions.title: A delivery person in uniform asks you to hold the secure door open because their hands are full.
questions.explanation: This is 'tailgating'. Uniforms can be faked. Everyone should use their own credentials to enter.

questions.title: What is 'baiting' in social engineering?
options: Leaving infected USB drives in public places
questions.correct_answer: Leaving infected USB drives in public places
questions.explanation: Baiting exploits curiosity by leaving malware-infected devices where victims will find and use them.

questions.title: A vendor calls requesting sensitive company information. How should you verify their identity?
options: Call them back using the official vendor contact number you have on file
Trust them if they know your name
questions.correct_answer: Call them back using the official vendor contact number you have on file
questions.explanation: Always verify using contact information you already have, not information provided by the caller.

questions.title: Creating urgency is a psychological manipulation tactic used to bypass rational thinking.
questions.explanation: Urgency exploits fear and scarcity to make victims act quickly without proper verification.

questions.title: A well-dressed visitor with a badge asks to use your computer 'for just a minute' to check their email.
questions.explanation: Visitor badges don't authorize computer access. Redirect them to reception or IT.

questions.title: What is 'quid pro quo' in social engineering?
options: Offering something in exchange for information or access
questions.correct_answer: Offering something in exchange for information or access
questions.explanation: Quid pro quo attacks offer help or rewards in exchange for credentials or sensitive information.

questions.title: Social engineers research targets on LinkedIn to make their attacks more convincing.
questions.explanation: Social media provides personal details that make pretexts more believable and personalized.

questions.title: What is 'shoulder surfing'?
options: Observing someone's screen or keyboard to steal information
questions.correct_answer: Observing someone's screen or keyboard to steal information
questions.explanation: Shoulder surfing is watching someone enter passwords or view sensitive information on their screen.

questions.title: An attacker poses as a new employee and asks for help accessing the network. What principle are they exploiting?
questions.explanation: Attackers exploit our natural desire to help others, especially those who appear vulnerable or new.

questions.title: Vishing is voice phishing conducted via phone calls.
questions.explanation: Vishing uses phone calls to trick victims into revealing sensitive information.

questions.title: A caller claims your computer has a virus and offers to fix it remotely for free.
questions.explanation: This is a tech support scam. Legitimate companies don't cold-call about viruses.

questions.title: How can you protect against dumpster diving attacks?
options: Shred all sensitive documents before disposal
questions.correct_answer: Shred all sensitive documents before disposal
questions.explanation: Cross-cut shredding prevents document reconstruction from discarded papers.

questions.title: What makes authority-based social engineering effective?
options: People naturally comply with perceived authority figures
questions.correct_answer: People naturally comply with perceived authority figures
questions.explanation: The authority principle means people tend to obey perceived authority without questioning.

questions.title: Smishing is phishing conducted via SMS text messages.
questions.explanation: Smishing uses SMS text messages to deliver phishing attacks to mobile devices.

questions.title: Someone on LinkedIn claiming to work at your company sends you a connection request. You don't recognize them.
questions.explanation: Verify their identity through internal channels before accepting. Fake profiles are used for reconnaissance.

questions.title: Why do attackers often target receptionists and help desk staff?
options: They have access to information and can provide entry points
questions.correct_answer: They have access to information and can provide entry points
questions.explanation: Front-line staff often have access to directories, can transfer calls, and control physical access.

questions.title: What is the BEST defense against social engineering?
options: Security awareness training and verification procedures
questions.correct_answer: Security awareness training and verification procedures
questions.explanation: Technical controls can't stop social engineering. Training and verification procedures are essential.

questions.title: The 'foot-in-the-door' technique starts with a small request before making a larger one.
questions.explanation: Small initial requests make victims more likely to comply with larger requests later.

name: Password Security Best Practices
description: Learn how to create strong passwords, use password managers effectively, and protect credentials.

questions.title: Which password is the STRONGEST?
questions.explanation: Long passphrases with random words are stronger than short complex passwords. Length beats complexity.

questions.title: Modern security guidelines recommend changing passwords every 30-90 days.
questions.explanation: NIST guidelines now recommend changing passwords only when compromised, as frequent changes lead to weaker passwords.

questions.title: What is a 'credential stuffing' attack?
options: Using leaked credentials from one site to access others
questions.correct_answer: Using leaked credentials from one site to access others
questions.explanation: Credential stuffing uses breached username/password pairs to access other accounts where users reused credentials.

questions.title: Using the same password for multiple accounts is safe if the password is complex.
questions.explanation: If one account is breached, all accounts with that password are vulnerable regardless of complexity.

questions.title: What is the MAIN benefit of using a password manager?
options: They allow unique complex passwords for every account
They eliminate the need for passwords
questions.correct_answer: They allow unique complex passwords for every account
questions.explanation: Password managers generate and store unique complex passwords, eliminating reuse.

questions.title: Storing your passwords in a text file on your desktop.
questions.explanation: Plain text files are easily accessible to anyone with access to your computer or malware.

questions.title: What is a 'brute force' attack?
questions.explanation: Brute force systematically tries all possible passwords. Longer passwords exponentially increase the time required.

questions.title: A dictionary attack uses common words and predictable patterns to guess passwords.
questions.explanation: Dictionary attacks try common words, phrases, and patterns like 'Password1!' before brute force.

questions.title: What minimum password length is recommended for strong security?
questions.explanation: Modern recommendations suggest at least 12-16 characters. Longer passphrases are even better.

questions.title: Using 'Summer2024!' as your password because it's easy to remember.
questions.explanation: Seasonal words with years are predictable patterns that attackers specifically target.

questions.title: What is 'password spraying'?
options: Trying common passwords against many accounts
questions.correct_answer: Trying common passwords against many accounts
questions.explanation: Password spraying tries a few common passwords across many accounts to avoid lockouts.

questions.title: Security questions like 'mother's maiden name' are secure because only you know the answer.
questions.explanation: Security question answers are often on social media or public records. Use fictional answers stored in a password manager.

questions.title: What should you do if you learn a service you use has been breached?
options: Wait for them to contact you
Change your password immediately and any other accounts using the same password
questions.correct_answer: Change your password immediately and any other accounts using the same password
questions.explanation: Act immediately to change compromised credentials and anywhere you've reused them.

questions.title: Using your birthday and pet's name combined as a password.
questions.explanation: Personal information is easily discoverable on social media and commonly used in targeted attacks.

questions.title: What is 'salting' in password security?
options: Adding random data to passwords before hashing
questions.correct_answer: Adding random data to passwords before hashing
questions.explanation: Salting adds unique random data to each password before hashing, preventing rainbow table attacks.

questions.title: Keyloggers can capture passwords regardless of their length or complexity.
questions.explanation: Keyloggers record everything typed, capturing passwords even if they're long and complex.

questions.title: Why should your password manager's master password be memorized?
options: It provides access to all passwords - if compromised, everything is at risk
Password managers don't allow written passwords
questions.correct_answer: It provides access to all passwords - if compromised, everything is at risk
questions.explanation: The master password unlocks all credentials. It must be strong, unique, and memorized.

questions.title: Sharing your Netflix password with family members.
questions.explanation: Shared passwords can be reused on other sites and spread beyond intended recipients.

questions.title: What is the purpose of password hashing?
options: To store passwords securely without keeping the actual password
questions.correct_answer: To store passwords securely without keeping the actual password
questions.explanation: Hashing creates a one-way fingerprint. Services verify passwords without storing the actual password.

questions.title: Two-factor authentication makes a weak password acceptable.
questions.explanation: 2FA adds security but doesn't replace strong passwords. Both are needed for proper protection.

name: Ransomware Awareness
description: Learn how ransomware works, prevention methods, and what to do if systems are compromised.

questions.title: What is ransomware?
options: Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for decryption
questions.correct_answer: Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for decryption
questions.explanation: Ransomware encrypts victim files and demands payment (usually cryptocurrency) for the decryption key.

questions.title: Paying the ransom guarantees you will get your files back.
questions.explanation: Payment doesn't guarantee decryption and funds criminal operations. Restore from backups instead.

questions.title: What is the MOST common delivery method for ransomware?
options: Phishing emails with malicious attachments or links
questions.correct_answer: Phishing emails with malicious attachments or links
questions.explanation: Phishing emails are the primary vector for ransomware delivery.

questions.title: Opening an email attachment named 'Important_Document.docm' from an unknown sender.
questions.explanation: .docm files are macro-enabled and can execute ransomware without additional user interaction.

questions.title: What is the BEST protection against ransomware?
options: Regular tested offline backups combined with security awareness
questions.correct_answer: Regular tested offline backups combined with security awareness
questions.explanation: Tested offline backups allow recovery without paying. Security awareness prevents initial infection.

questions.title: Ransomware can encrypt backup drives that are connected to infected computers.
questions.explanation: Ransomware actively targets connected backups. Air-gapped/offline backups can't be encrypted remotely.

questions.title: What should you do IMMEDIATELY if you suspect ransomware infection?
options: Disconnect from the network and report to IT immediately
questions.correct_answer: Disconnect from the network and report to IT immediately
questions.explanation: Disconnecting prevents spread to other systems. IT can begin incident response procedures.

questions.title: Enabling macros in a Word document sent from an unknown source to view its contents.
questions.explanation: Malicious macros can execute ransomware automatically. Never enable macros from untrusted sources.

questions.title: What is 'double extortion' ransomware?
options: Attackers steal data AND encrypt it, threatening to leak if not paid
questions.correct_answer: Attackers steal data AND encrypt it, threatening to leak if not paid
questions.explanation: Double extortion pressures victims to pay even if they have backups to prevent data leaks.

questions.title: The 3-2-1 backup rule means: 3 copies, 2 different storage types, 1 offsite.
questions.explanation: 3-2-1 ensures redundancy and protects against various disaster scenarios including ransomware.

questions.title: What is 'Ransomware-as-a-Service' (RaaS)?
options: Criminal business model where developers rent ransomware to affiliates
questions.correct_answer: Criminal business model where developers rent ransomware to affiliates
questions.explanation: RaaS allows criminals without technical skills to launch ransomware attacks using tools from developers.

questions.title: Clicking a link in an email that says 'Your package could not be delivered. Click here to reschedule.'
questions.explanation: Fake delivery notifications are common ransomware delivery methods. Verify with the shipping company directly.

questions.title: Why do ransomware attackers often demand cryptocurrency payments?
options: Cryptocurrency is harder to trace and doesn't require traditional banking
questions.correct_answer: Cryptocurrency is harder to trace and doesn't require traditional banking
questions.explanation: Cryptocurrency provides anonymity and doesn't require traceable banking systems.

questions.title: Free ransomware decryption tools may be available from security researchers.
questions.explanation: Sites like NoMoreRansom.org provide free decryptors when researchers crack ransomware or obtain keys.

questions.title: What role does software patching play in ransomware prevention?
options: Critical - many attacks exploit known vulnerabilities with available patches
questions.correct_answer: Critical - many attacks exploit known vulnerabilities with available patches
questions.explanation: WannaCry and many others exploited unpatched systems. Regular patching closes vulnerability gaps.

questions.title: Using Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) with a simple password exposed to the internet.
questions.explanation: Exposed RDP with weak credentials is a major ransomware entry point. Use VPN, strong passwords, and MFA.

questions.title: What is network segmentation's role in limiting ransomware damage?
options: It limits spread by isolating network sections
questions.correct_answer: It limits spread by isolating network sections
questions.explanation: Segmentation contains outbreaks by preventing ransomware from spreading across the entire network.

questions.title: Modern attackers often spend days or weeks inside networks before deploying ransomware.
questions.explanation: Attackers use 'dwell time' to map systems and steal data before encryption for maximum impact.

questions.title: What should be included in a ransomware incident response plan?
options: Isolation procedures, communication plans, backup restoration steps, and reporting requirements
questions.correct_answer: Isolation procedures, communication plans, backup restoration steps, and reporting requirements
questions.explanation: Comprehensive plans ensure quick, coordinated responses that minimize damage.

questions.title: Keeping your operating system and applications updated with the latest security patches.
questions.explanation: Regular updates patch vulnerabilities that ransomware exploits. This is essential security hygiene.

name: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
description: Understand authentication factors, MFA implementation, and why it's crucial for security.

questions.title: What are the three main categories of authentication factors?
options: Something you know, something you have, something you are
questions.correct_answer: Something you know, something you have, something you are
questions.explanation: Knowledge (passwords), possession (phone/token), and inherence (biometrics) are the three factor categories.

questions.title: MFA is more secure because attackers need to compromise multiple independent factors.
questions.explanation: MFA requires multiple independent proofs of identity, making compromise much harder.

questions.title: Which MFA method is considered MOST secure?
questions.explanation: Hardware keys are phishing-resistant and can't be intercepted like SMS or email codes.

questions.title: Using SMS text messages as your only second factor for banking.
questions.explanation: SMS can be intercepted through SIM swapping, SS7 attacks, or phone theft. Use authenticator apps when possible.

questions.title: What is a 'SIM swap' attack?
options: Attackers convince carriers to transfer your phone number to their SIM
questions.correct_answer: Attackers convince carriers to transfer your phone number to their SIM
questions.explanation: SIM swapping hijacks your phone number, allowing attackers to receive your SMS codes.

questions.title: Authenticator apps generate codes that work offline because they use time-based algorithms.
questions.explanation: TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password) uses a shared secret and current time to generate codes without internet.

questions.title: What should you do with MFA backup codes?
options: Store them securely offline in case you lose your MFA device
questions.correct_answer: Store them securely offline in case you lose your MFA device
questions.explanation: Backup codes are recovery options. Store them securely but separately from your MFA device.

questions.title: Approving an MFA push notification that you didn't request while trying to stop the notifications.
questions.explanation: This is 'MFA fatigue'. Attackers spam notifications hoping you'll approve one. Report unexpected prompts.

questions.title: You receive an MFA code you didn't request. What does this indicate?
options: Someone may have your password and is trying to log in
questions.correct_answer: Someone may have your password and is trying to log in
questions.explanation: Unrequested codes indicate someone has your password. Change it immediately.

questions.title: FIDO2/WebAuthn security keys are phishing-resistant because they verify the website's identity.
questions.explanation: FIDO2 keys cryptographically verify the actual website domain, refusing to authenticate on phishing sites.

questions.title: What is 'MFA fatigue' or 'MFA bombing'?
options: Attackers spam push notifications until users approve out of frustration
questions.correct_answer: Attackers spam push notifications until users approve out of frustration
questions.explanation: MFA bombing sends repeated prompts hoping users approve one to stop the annoyance.

questions.title: Sharing your MFA code with someone who calls claiming to be IT support.
questions.explanation: Legitimate IT NEVER needs your MFA codes. Anyone asking is likely an attacker.

questions.title: What should you do if you lose your phone with an authenticator app?
options: Use backup codes and set up MFA on a new device immediately
questions.correct_answer: Use backup codes and set up MFA on a new device immediately
questions.explanation: Use backup codes to regain access, then immediately set up MFA on a new device.

questions.title: Number-matching in push notification MFA prevents accidental approvals.
questions.explanation: Number matching requires entering a specific code, preventing MFA fatigue attacks and accidents.

questions.title: Which accounts should have MFA enabled as a PRIORITY?
options: Email, banking, social media, and any account with sensitive data
questions.correct_answer: Email, banking, social media, and any account with sensitive data
questions.explanation: Email is especially critical as it's used for password resets. All sensitive accounts need MFA.

questions.title: Using the same phone for both your banking app and receiving SMS MFA codes for banking.
questions.explanation: If your phone is compromised, attackers have both the app and the second factor, defeating MFA.

questions.title: What is a 'passkey'?
options: A master key for all accounts
A passwordless authentication method using cryptographic keys
questions.correct_answer: A passwordless authentication method using cryptographic keys
questions.explanation: Passkeys use device-stored cryptographic credentials, eliminating passwords while being phishing-resistant.

questions.title: Biometric authentication like fingerprints is considered 'something you are'.
questions.explanation: Biometrics use unique physical characteristics (fingerprints, face) as authentication factors.

questions.title: What is 'step-up authentication'?
options: Requiring additional verification for sensitive actions after initial login
questions.correct_answer: Requiring additional verification for sensitive actions after initial login
questions.explanation: Step-up auth requires extra verification for high-risk actions like large transfers.

questions.title: Enabling MFA on your email account that's used for password resets on other sites.
questions.explanation: Your email is a critical security point. Protecting it with MFA prevents account takeovers.

name: USB & Physical Security
description: Learn about USB security risks, physical access threats, and protecting against physical breaches.

questions.title: You find a USB drive labeled 'Salary Info 2024' in the parking lot. What should you do?
options: Plug it in to find the owner
Turn it in to security without connecting it to any device
Check it on a public computer
questions.correct_answer: Turn it in to security without connecting it to any device
questions.explanation: USB baiting drops labeled drives hoping curiosity leads someone to connect an infected device.

questions.title: A 'USB Rubber Ducky' device appears as a keyboard to execute malicious commands rapidly.
questions.explanation: Rubber Ducky devices look like USB drives but act as keyboards, typing malicious commands instantly.

questions.title: Charging your phone using a USB port at a public charging station.
questions.explanation: 'Juice jacking' uses USB data connections in public chargers to install malware or steal data.

questions.title: What is 'tailgating' in physical security?
options: Following an authorized person through a secured entrance
questions.correct_answer: Following an authorized person through a secured entrance
questions.explanation: Tailgating bypasses access controls by following authorized personnel through secured doors.

questions.title: A 'USB Killer' device can physically destroy computer hardware with electrical surges.
questions.explanation: USB Killers look like flash drives but deliver voltage surges that physically destroy equipment.

questions.title: Leaving your laptop unlocked and unattended while getting coffee.
questions.explanation: An unlocked computer gives access to email, files, applications, and network resources.

questions.title: How should visitors be handled in a secure facility?
options: Escort them at all times with visible badges and sign-in/out
questions.correct_answer: Escort them at all times with visible badges and sign-in/out
questions.explanation: Visitor management prevents unauthorized access and maintains accountability.

questions.title: Screen privacy filters prevent shoulder surfing by limiting screen visibility angles.
questions.explanation: Privacy filters prevent people beside or behind you from reading your screen.

questions.title: Using a promotional USB drive received at a conference without scanning it.
questions.explanation: Promotional drives can be pre-infected with malware. Only use USB devices from trusted sources.

questions.title: What should you do if you see someone without a badge in a restricted area?
options: Politely ask if they need assistance and alert security if needed
questions.correct_answer: Politely ask if they need assistance and alert security if needed
questions.explanation: Challenge unknown individuals politely but firmly. Social engineers rely on people not questioning them.

questions.title: Full disk encryption protects data even if the physical device is stolen.
questions.explanation: Encryption makes data unreadable without the decryption key, even with physical access.

questions.title: Using your own charger with an electrical outlet instead of public USB ports.
questions.explanation: Your own charger with electrical outlets prevents juice jacking attacks.

questions.title: What is a 'mantrap' in physical security?
options: A small room with two interlocking doors where only one opens at a time
questions.correct_answer: A small room with two interlocking doors where only one opens at a time
questions.explanation: Mantraps prevent tailgating by requiring individual authentication between two doors.

questions.title: Reporting lost or stolen devices immediately allows IT to remotely wipe them.
questions.explanation: Quick reporting enables remote wipe or lock before attackers can access data.

questions.title: Holding the secure door open for someone carrying boxes who says they forgot their badge.
questions.explanation: This is piggybacking. Ask them to contact security or reception instead.

questions.title: What is a 'clean desk policy'?
options: Ensuring sensitive materials are secured when not in use
questions.correct_answer: Ensuring sensitive materials are secured when not in use
questions.explanation: Clean desk policies prevent data exposure from visible documents and unlocked screens.

questions.title: An 'air gap' physically isolates a system from unsecured networks for maximum security.
questions.explanation: Air-gapped systems have no network connection, protecting highly sensitive data from remote attacks.

questions.title: Leaving sensitive printed documents in the printer tray overnight.
questions.explanation: Documents should be retrieved immediately and shredded when done to prevent exposure.

questions.title: What is 'BadUSB'?
options: Malware that reprograms USB firmware to perform malicious actions
questions.correct_answer: Malware that reprograms USB firmware to perform malicious actions
questions.explanation: BadUSB reprograms the USB controller itself, making the device malicious at the hardware level.

questions.title: Using a USB data blocker when charging your phone at airports.
questions.explanation: USB data blockers allow charging while blocking data transfer, preventing juice jacking.

name: Data Protection & Privacy
description: Understand data classification, handling sensitive information, and privacy regulations.

questions.title: What type of data requires the HIGHEST level of protection?
options: Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and financial data
questions.correct_answer: Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and financial data
questions.explanation: PII and financial data have legal protections and severe consequences if breached.

questions.title: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) is the EU's comprehensive data protection law.
questions.explanation: GDPR is the European Union's comprehensive data protection and privacy regulation.

questions.title: Emailing a spreadsheet with customer credit card numbers to your personal email for remote work.
questions.explanation: Sensitive data should never be sent to personal email. Use approved secure methods.

questions.title: What is data minimization?
options: Collecting only data necessary for a specific purpose
questions.correct_answer: Collecting only data necessary for a specific purpose
questions.explanation: Data minimization means collecting only what's needed, reducing risk if a breach occurs.

questions.title: The principle of 'least privilege' means users should only have access necessary for their job.
questions.explanation: Least privilege limits access to reduce damage if an account is compromised.

questions.title: Discussing confidential client information loudly in a coffee shop.
questions.explanation: Sensitive conversations can be overheard, leading to data leaks or competitive intelligence theft.

questions.title: How should sensitive printed documents be disposed of?
questions.explanation: Sensitive documents require secure destruction to prevent dumpster diving attacks.

questions.title: A data breach is any unauthorized access, disclosure, or loss of protected data.
questions.explanation: Data breaches include accidental exposure, not just malicious attacks.

questions.title: Using encryption when sending sensitive documents via email.
questions.explanation: Encryption protects data in transit from interception.

questions.title: What should you do if you accidentally send sensitive data to the wrong person?
options: Report it immediately to your security team
questions.correct_answer: Report it immediately to your security team
questions.explanation: Data incidents require immediate reporting to enable proper response and compliance.

questions.title: 'Data at rest' refers to stored data, while 'data in transit' is data being transmitted.
questions.explanation: Both need protection but with different methods - encryption at rest and in transit.

questions.title: Storing customer data on a USB drive to work from home.
questions.explanation: USB drives can be lost or stolen. Use approved secure remote access methods.

questions.title: What is 'data retention'?
options: Policies defining how long data is kept before secure deletion
questions.correct_answer: Policies defining how long data is kept before secure deletion
questions.explanation: Data retention policies specify storage duration and secure deletion requirements.

questions.title: Individuals have the right under GDPR to request all data a company has about them.
questions.explanation: GDPR grants data subjects the right to access their personal data held by organizations.

questions.title: Leaving your computer logged in and unlocked when going to lunch.
questions.explanation: Always lock your computer (Win+L or Cmd+Ctrl+Q) when stepping away.

questions.title: What is a DPA (Data Processing Agreement)?
options: A contract governing how third parties handle your data
questions.correct_answer: A contract governing how third parties handle your data
questions.explanation: DPAs establish legal requirements for how vendors must protect shared data.

questions.title: Pseudonymization replaces identifying data with artificial identifiers while maintaining data utility.
questions.explanation: Pseudonymization protects identity while allowing data analysis, unlike full anonymization.

questions.title: Verifying the recipient's email address carefully before sending sensitive documents.
questions.explanation: Double-checking recipients prevents accidental data disclosure to wrong parties.

questions.title: How should you handle a USB drive found in the parking lot with a company label?
options: Plug it in to return it
Turn it in to IT/security without connecting it
questions.correct_answer: Turn it in to IT/security without connecting it
questions.explanation: Unknown devices could be malicious. Let security handle them safely.

questions.title: Data classification helps determine appropriate handling and protection levels.
questions.explanation: Classification ensures data receives protection appropriate to its sensitivity level.

name: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
description: Recognize and prevent BEC attacks including CEO fraud, invoice manipulation, and account compromise.

questions.title: What is Business Email Compromise (BEC)?
options: Sophisticated scams where attackers pose as trusted parties to steal money or data
questions.correct_answer: Sophisticated scams where attackers pose as trusted parties to steal money or data
questions.explanation: BEC uses social engineering to impersonate executives, vendors, or partners for fraud.

questions.title: CEO fraud involves attackers impersonating executives to request urgent wire transfers.
questions.explanation: CEO fraud pressures finance staff into urgent wire transfers by impersonating senior executives.

questions.title: Your CEO emails urgently asking you to wire $50,000 for a secret acquisition. They say not to tell anyone.
questions.explanation: Secrecy requests combined with urgency are major BEC red flags. Always verify via phone.

questions.title: A vendor emails that their bank account has changed. What should you do FIRST?
options: Verify through a known phone number before making changes
questions.correct_answer: Verify through a known phone number before making changes
questions.explanation: Payment change requests are common BEC tactics. Always verify via previously known contacts.

questions.title: BEC attacks often succeed because they exploit human trust rather than technical vulnerabilities.
questions.explanation: BEC relies on social engineering, bypassing technical security controls.

questions.title: Processing a wire transfer request from your CFO without verifying through a phone call.
questions.explanation: Always verify unusual financial requests via a separate channel like a phone call.

questions.title: What is 'account takeover' in BEC?
options: Attackers gain control of legitimate email accounts to send fraudulent messages
questions.correct_answer: Attackers gain control of legitimate email accounts to send fraudulent messages
questions.explanation: Account takeover makes detection harder since messages come from real, compromised accounts.

questions.title: BEC attackers research targets using LinkedIn and company websites before attacking.
questions.explanation: Attackers thoroughly research organizations to craft convincing, targeted requests.

questions.title: An email from your 'boss' asks you to buy $500 in gift cards for client gifts and email the codes.
questions.explanation: Gift card requests are a common BEC variant. Always verify unusual requests.

questions.title: What process BEST prevents unauthorized wire transfers?
options: Dual approval and out-of-band verification for large transfers
questions.correct_answer: Dual approval and out-of-band verification for large transfers
questions.explanation: Multiple approvals and separate verification channels prevent single-point fraud.

questions.title: Email authentication (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) helps prevent domain spoofing in BEC attacks.
questions.explanation: Email authentication prevents spoofing and helps identify impersonation attempts.

questions.title: An invoice arrives from a regular vendor but with different bank details than usual.
questions.explanation: Changed payment details on invoices are a major BEC red flag. Verify before paying.

questions.title: Why do BEC attacks often coincide with executive travel?
options: Verification is harder and urgency seems more believable
questions.correct_answer: Verification is harder and urgency seems more believable
questions.explanation: Attackers exploit situations where normal verification processes are disrupted.

questions.title: Look-alike domains (company-inc.com vs company.com) are used in BEC to appear legitimate.
questions.explanation: Similar domains add legitimacy. Users often don't notice small domain differences.

questions.title: Verifying a wire transfer request by calling the requester at their known phone number.
questions.explanation: Out-of-band verification through known contact information prevents BEC fraud.

questions.title: What is 'attorney impersonation' in BEC?
options: Attackers pose as lawyers handling confidential matters requiring urgent payment
questions.correct_answer: Attackers pose as lawyers handling confidential matters requiring urgent payment
questions.explanation: Attorney impersonation adds authority and secrecy pressure to payment requests.

questions.title: Finance and HR departments are prime BEC targets due to their access to money and data.
questions.explanation: Finance processes payments; HR handles sensitive data - both are high-value targets.

questions.title: An urgent email from a lawyer you've never heard of requests confidential documents for a secret deal.
questions.explanation: Unknown attorneys with urgent secret requests are classic BEC tactics.

questions.title: What should companies do IMMEDIATELY after falling victim to BEC?
options: Contact banks to recall transfers and report to law enforcement
questions.correct_answer: Contact banks to recall transfers and report to law enforcement
questions.explanation: Quick action can sometimes recover funds. Report to FBI IC3 and implement lessons learned.

questions.title: A culture where employees are encouraged to question unusual requests helps prevent BEC.
questions.explanation: Empowering employees to verify and question prevents social engineering success.

name: Secure Browsing & Downloads
description: Learn safe web browsing, identifying malicious websites, and secure download practices.

questions.title: A padlock icon in the browser address bar guarantees a website is safe and legitimate.
questions.explanation: HTTPS/padlock means encrypted connection, not that the site is safe. Phishing sites can have HTTPS too.

questions.title: Where should you download popular software from?
options: The software's official website or app store
questions.correct_answer: The software's official website or app store
questions.explanation: Official sources are verified. Third-party sites may bundle malware with legitimate software.

questions.title: Clicking 'proceed anyway' when your browser warns that a website's certificate is invalid.
questions.explanation: Certificate errors may indicate attacks or compromised servers. Don't proceed.

questions.title: Browser updates patch security vulnerabilities that attackers exploit.
questions.explanation: Browser updates fix security flaws. Outdated browsers are major attack targets.

questions.title: What is a 'drive-by download'?
options: Malware that downloads automatically just by visiting a webpage
questions.correct_answer: Malware that downloads automatically just by visiting a webpage
questions.explanation: Drive-by downloads exploit browser vulnerabilities to install malware without clicks.

questions.title: A website popup says your computer is infected and offers free antivirus download.
questions.explanation: Websites cannot scan your computer. These are scareware tactics to install malware.

questions.title: What is typosquatting?
options: Registering domains with common typos to catch users who mistype URLs
questions.correct_answer: Registering domains with common typos to catch users who mistype URLs
questions.explanation: Typosquatting catches typing errors to deliver malware or phishing.

questions.title: Adobe Flash Player was discontinued in 2020, so any 'Flash update' prompts are scams.
questions.explanation: Flash Player is discontinued. Any update prompts are malware delivery attempts.

questions.title: Installing browser extensions from unverified sources because they offer useful features.
questions.explanation: Malicious extensions can access all browsing data and credentials.

questions.title: What should you check BEFORE entering credentials on a website?
options: URL is correct, connection is HTTPS, and you navigated there directly
questions.correct_answer: URL is correct, connection is HTTPS, and you navigated there directly
questions.explanation: Verify the exact URL, ensure HTTPS, and access sensitive sites by typing URLs directly.

questions.title: Public Wi-Fi can be used safely for sensitive activities like banking.
questions.explanation: Public Wi-Fi enables traffic interception and evil twin attacks. Use VPN for sensitive activities.

questions.title: Downloading a 'free' premium software that normally costs $500 from an unofficial site.
questions.explanation: Free premium software often contains malware, is pirated, or lacks promised features.

questions.title: What is a 'watering hole attack'?
options: Compromising websites frequently visited by target groups
questions.correct_answer: Compromising websites frequently visited by target groups
questions.explanation: Watering hole attacks infect sites that specific target groups frequent.

questions.title: Incognito/private browsing makes you completely anonymous online.
questions.explanation: Private browsing only prevents local history storage. Websites, ISPs, and employers can still track you.

questions.title: Verifying the URL and looking for HTTPS before logging into your bank account.
questions.explanation: Always verify the exact URL and secure connection before entering credentials.

questions.title: What are browser extensions' security risks?
options: Malicious extensions can access all browsing data and credentials
questions.correct_answer: Malicious extensions can access all browsing data and credentials
questions.explanation: Extensions have broad permissions. Malicious ones can steal data and hijack sessions.

questions.title: Research software reputation and download only from official sources for safety.
questions.explanation: Researching and using official sources prevents malware bundled with software.

questions.title: Clicking the first search result ad for 'Adobe Reader download' without checking the URL.
questions.explanation: Search ads can be malicious. Navigate directly to official websites for software.

questions.title: What is browser fingerprinting?
options: Tracking users by collecting unique browser and system characteristics
questions.correct_answer: Tracking users by collecting unique browser and system characteristics
questions.explanation: Fingerprinting identifies users by combining browser settings, plugins, and other attributes.

questions.title: Pop-up prize claims asking for personal information to claim rewards are legitimate.
questions.explanation: Pop-up prize claims are always scams designed to harvest personal information.
